natural problem:
The complete graph of $y=f(x)$, which consists of five line segments, is shown in red below. (On this graph, the distance between grid lines is $1$.)

What is the sum of the $x$-coordinates of all points where $f(x) = x+1$?
natural solution: We superimpose the graph of $y=x+1$ on the same axes as the original graph: [asy] size(150); real ticklen=3; real tickspace=2; real ticklength=0.1cm; real axisarrowsize=0.14cm; pen axispen=black+1.3bp;

real vectorarrowsize=0.2cm; real tickdown=-0.5; real tickdownlength=-0.15inch; real tickdownbase=0.3; real wholetickdown=tickdown; void rr_cartesian_axes(real xleft, real xright, real ybottom, real ytop, real xstep=1, real ystep=1, bool useticks=false, bool complexplane=false, bool usegrid=true) {

import graph; real i; if(complexplane) { label("$\textnormal{Re}$",(xright,0),SE); label("$\textnormal{Im}$",(0,ytop),NW); } else { label("$x$",(xright+0.4,-0.5)); label("$y$",(-0.5,ytop+0.2)); } ylimits(ybottom,ytop);

xlimits( xleft, xright); real[] TicksArrx,TicksArry; for(i=xleft+xstep; i<xright; i+=xstep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArrx.push(i); } } for(i=ybottom+ystep; i<ytop; i+=ystep) { if(abs(i) >0.1) { TicksArry.push(i);

} } if(usegrid) { xaxis(BottomTop(extend=false), Ticks("%", TicksArrx ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true),p=invisible);//,above=true); yaxis(LeftRight(extend=false),Ticks("%", TicksArry ,pTick=gray(0.22),extend=true), p=invisible);//,Arrows);

} if(useticks) { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArry , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, Ticks("%",TicksArrx , pTick=black+0.8bp,Size=ticklength), above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize));

} else { xequals(0, ymin=ybottom, ymax=ytop, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); yequals(0, xmin=xleft, xmax=xright, p=axispen, above=true, Arrows(size=axisarrowsize)); } }; rr_cartesian_axes(-5,5,-5,5);

draw((-4,-5)--(-2,-1)--(-1,-2)--(1,2)--(2,1)--(4,5),red); draw((-5,-4)--(4,5),green); [/asy] There are three intersections, at $(-2,-1),$ $(1,2),$ and $(4,5)$. The sum of their $x$-coordinates is $(-2)+1+4=\boxed{3}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (if x \<le> -2 then x + 3
                      else if x \<le> -1 then -x - 1
                      else if x \<le> 1 then x + 1
                      else if x \<le> 2 then -x + 3
                      else x - 1)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = x + 1 \<longrightarrow> x \<in> {0, 1, 2}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. x) {0, 1, 2} = 3"
a_0.informal problem:
Given a piecewise function $f(x)$ defined as follows:

$$
f(x) =
\begin{cases}
  x + 3, & \text{if}\ x \le -2 \\
  -x - 1, & \text{if}\ -2 < x \le -1 \\
  x + 1, & \text{if}\ -1 < x \le 1 \\
  -x + 3, & \text{if}\ 1 < x \le 2 \\
  x - 1, & \text{if}\ x > 2
\end{cases}
$$

For which values of $x$ does $f(x) = x + 1$? The final answer is the sum of these values, which is $3$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x + 1"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = x"
and h2 : "\<exists> x. g x = f x"
shows  "sum_list (map g [x. g x = f x]) = 3"
a_1.informal problem: Find the sum of all values $x$ such that $g(x) = f(x)$. Here, the function $f$ is defined such that $f(x) = x + 1$ and the function $g$ is defined such that $g(x) = x$. The final answer is 3.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x + 1"
and h1 : "\<exists>x. f x = x + 1"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. x) {x. f x = x + 1} = 3"
a_2.informal problem: Given a function $f(x) = x + 1$, find the sum of all $x$ such that $f(x) = x + 1$. The final answer is $3$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = x + 1"
and h2 : "finite {x. f x = x + 1}"
shows  "sum id {x. f x = x + 1} = 3"
a_3.informal problem: Given a bijective function $f(x) = x + 1$ for all real numbers $x$, if the set of all $x$ such that $f(x) = x + 1$ is finite, then the sum of all such $x$ is 3.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = x + 1"
and h1 : "\<exists> x1 x2 x3. {x1, x2, x3} \<subseteq> {x. f x = x + 1} \<and> x1 + x2 + x3 = 3"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. x) {x. f x = x + 1} = 3"
a_4.informal problem: Let $f(x) = x + 1$. Find three such $x$ values, denoted as $x1, x2, x3$, for which the sum of these values equals $3$. The final answer is that the sum of all such $x$ values is $3$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = piecewise (\<lambda>x. x - 3) (x \<le> 0) (\<lambda>x. x - 1) (x > 0 \<and> x \<le> 1) (\<lambda>x. x + 1) (x > 1 \<and> x \<le> 2) (\<lambda>x. x + 3) (x > 2 \<and> x \<le> 3) (\<lambda>x. x + 5) (x > 3)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f x = x + 1"
shows  "sum_list (map fst (filter (\<lambda>(x, y). y = f x) (map (\<lambda>x. (x, x + 1)) [0..4]))) = 3"
a_5.informal problem:
Define a function $f(x)$ as follows:

- If $x \le 0$, then $f(x) = x - 3$.
- If $0 < x \le 1$, then $f(x) = x - 1$.
- If $1 < x \le 2$, then $f(x) = x + 1$.
- If $2 < x \le 3$, then $f(x) = x + 3$.
- If $x > 3$, then $f(x) = x + 5$.

Now, consider the function $g(x) = x + 1$. Find the sum of all integers $x$ in the range $0$ to $4$ such that $f(x) = g(x)$. The final answer is $3$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
and x :: real
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = x + 1"
and h1 : "finite {(x, f x) | x. True}"
and h2 : "card {(x, f x) | x. True} = 5"
shows  "(\<Sum>x | x \<in> {x. f x = x + 1}. x) = 3"
a_6.informal problem: Consider a function $f(x) = x + 1$. If there are exactly five distinct points $(x, f(x))$ such that they form a finite set, find the sum of all those $x$ values. The final answer is $3$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "piecewise_linear f"
and h1 : "card {x. f x = x + 1} = 3"
shows  "(\<Sum>x\<in>{x. f x = x + 1}. x) = 3"
a_7.informal problem: Given a piecewise linear function $f(x)$, there are three points where $f(x) = x + 1$. Find the sum of the x-coordinates of these points. The final answer is $3$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. f x = piecewise (\<lambda>x. x + 1) {x. 0 \<le> x \<and> x \<le> 3} (\<lambda>x. 4 - x) {x. 3 < x \<and> x \<le> 4}"
and h1 : "finite {x. f x = x + 1}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. x) {x. f x = x + 1} = 3"
a_8.informal problem: Consider a piecewise function $f(x)$ defined as follows: $f(x) = x + 1$ for $0 \le x \le 3$ and $f(x) = 4 - x$ for $3 < x \le 4$. Find the sum of all $x$ values such that $f(x) = x + 1$. The final answer is $3$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = (if x \<in> {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} then x + 1 else undefined)"
and h1 : "finite {x. f x = x + 1}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>x. x) {x. f x = x + 1} = 3"
a_9.informal problem: A function $f(x)$ is defined as follows: if $x \in \{0, 1, 2, 3, 4\}$, then $f(x) = x + 1$, otherwise, it is undefined. Calculate the sum of all $x$'s for which $f(x) = x + 1$. The final answer is 3.
